p.seg: Among the people there was one who made thievery his profession.
He taught his son all about his craft.
The son of the thief was proud of his own talent
and he considered himself superior to his father by far.
the son of the thief would invariably enter first and leave last,
Everytime they went thieving,
he would leave aside the light (goods) and only take the heavy ones.
his eyes were able to see in the dark
And he was praised by all the thieves.
His ears were able to hear a long distance,
He boasted, comparing himself with his father and said "I am not lacking in any way, compared to the old one's craft
and I do surpass him in hardness and strength.
On the Thief and His Son
The thief said: "It is not quite like this.
As for wise and thorough learning and abundant self-posession,
you are not there yet".
If it goes on like this,
what worry is there about my success."
The son of the thief said: "In the principles of thievery
gaining valuables is considered success.
As for me and the old one,
my success is always greater than his.
Now I am still young of years,
but when I reach the old one's age,
I will then have techniques of a totally different nature."
The thief said: "It is not quite like this.
When using my craft,
one can enter multi-layered walls,
and one can find out hidden treasure hoards.
But if there is but a single slip or error,
disaster and woe will follow it.
When no traces are left that can be followed,
when one conforms to the changes in the situation and one cannot be trapped,
You are not there yet."
The son of the thief still did not heed this lesson
In the next night, the thief, together with his son, entered a wealthy house.
He told his son to enter into the treasury.
The thief's son was taking a huge ammount of valuable goods,
when the thief shut the door and turned the key.
The noise was heard by the master of the house
and saw that the lock was in place as it had been.
The thief's son was inside the treasury,
with no plan to get out.
The master returned inside.
Through scratching and crawling, he made the noise of mice biting and chewing.
When the master heard that a mouse was inside the treasury damaging the goods,
he could not avoid going out again.
When he held up a lantern and opened the lock to have a look,
the thief's son escaped and ran.
The master's household all together chased him.
The thief's son was distressed,
believing that he would not be able to escape
he ran, heading for the moat.
He tossed a stone into the water,
so that the chasers exclaimed that the thief had entered the water
and they guarded the fence, trying to find and catch (the thief).
The thief's son was able to escape because of this.
He blamed his father, saying: "Even birds and beasts know how to care for their children
Now, thievery is a base and ugly craft,
but it still takes ones own experience to be able to face the world.
This is exactly like when the thief's son boasts before his father.
Do not be confused!
If one can do away with honour and live humbly,
if one declines grandeur and follows what one loves in peacefulness and unimportance,
in frugality and with ones mind focused on study,
with ones heart-mind sunken deeply into the cosmic order;
and if one is not moved by base customs,
one can then be in harmony with other people
and can gain merits and fame.
That is exactly how the thief's son gained wisdom through distress
and in the end became one who could stride the world on his own.
You are also close to this.
You should not be afraid of a sudden pursuit by a calamity while you are in hiding (like the thief in the treasury).
and everything will go well and orderly.
One works or keeps to oneself, according to being in office or being in hiding,
then this is something that can not be performed by someone who does not have first-hand experience.
the household chased away the thief and then returned
The thief said: "From now on
you will now have to stride the world alone.
As for all the skills of men,
those that are learned from others
are only partially understood.
Those that are learned by oneself
are inexhaustible in their application.
My bringing you into distress
was to put you into safety.
My trapping you
was to free you.
Had their been no entering the treasury and the hardship of being chased,
how would you have been able to come up with the ruses of chewing like a mouse and throwing a stone?
It was because of the difficulties that you became wise
and facing disaster you came up with the ruses.
Once the deeps of the heart-mind have opened
they will not again return to confusion.
You indeed will have to stride the world alone now.
In the end, he became a thief that was unmatched in the world.
What have I, your son, done wrong
that you are mistreating me like this?"
And moreover as for difficulties and distress, as for utter desolation,
they are what strengthens a person's will and grows a person's benevolence.
And moreover, as for the gentleman's attitude towards doctrine, virtue, merits, and fame.
The descendants of officials, adorned with the correct hairstyle and with a hereditary salary,
they do not know the beauty of benevolence and righteousness and the profits of scholarly learning.
?????Those who already have fame and honour
?????can equal the heroes of the past and surpass the older exploits.
Think of what you have gained yourself in your hear-mind and it will be good.
